awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Belling the CAD: Towards Security-Centric Electronic System Level Design
awd_abstract_narration:
An Integrated Circuit (ICs) is at the core of many critical applications from financial and healthcare to avionics and military applications. Trustworthy ICs are therefore fundamental in ensuring the safety and security of our society. Unfortunately, cost considerations and globalization have pushed the IC design to a decentralized and distributed paradigm, where the design of a system-on-an-IC (SOC) spans various companies and countries with the fabrication of these SoCs taking place in third party (offshore) foundries. Threats, such as hardware Trojans, intellectual property piracy, and reverse engineering have emerged. This makes IC designers question their trust in the SOCs that they design. As SoCs are the roots of trust, applications that run on a compromised SOC platform is vulnerable regardless of how secure the underlying operating system and software is.
 
Complexity of ICs has been growing exponentially. To keep pace with this complexity, electronic system level (ESL) computer aided design (CAD) tools are being used to design ICs, resulting in simpler and automated design processes and shorter design cycles. This project develops a security-aware ESL design tool flow, and demonstrates the security vulnerabilities in industry standard ESL design flows by showing how one can reverse engineer an ESL generated design. This research develops approaches to build security into the ESL design flow, yielding reverse-engineering-resilient SoCs and systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project developed asecurity aware electonic computer aided design tools. The TAO and ASSURE tools lock designs to thwart intellectual property (IP) theft of the design. Another tool integrates taint propagation and monitoring hardware in designs. It also develops electonic computer aided design tools to compose trustworthy designs out of untrustworthy IPs. Overall, it develops Security-aware HLS flows targeting a range of security metrics: obfuscation, locking, trojan detection, taint propagation, and watermarking.  The project evaluated the security-aware HLS on large open benchmarks including MIT Lincoln Labs Common Evaluation Platforms and Openroad. 

An adversarial theme explores the use of HLS for introducing Trojans and other attacks. Trojans can be inserted directly by a rogue employee or through a compromised computer-aided design tool at each step of the design cycle, including an alteration of the design files in the early stages and the fabrication process in a third-party malicious foundry. While Trojan insertion during the latter stages has been largely investigated, this project highlights HLS tools as a likely attack vector. 

Along an orthogonal dimension, the project developed Xilinx Vivado synthesizable C codes of post quantum algorithms. All the code are publicly available for the community to use and improve. These codes have been used to demonstrate verification of HLS-synthesized PQC accelerators by a Stanford team. We implemented HLS-based hardware architectures of these eight PQC algorithms on the Artix-7 FPGA. We verified the algorithms using Known Answer Tests (KATs). 

The project trained students and the outcomes are available as peer-reviewed conference and journal publications. Further, the PI has delivered several talks to disseminate the developed technologies.


Last Modified: 12/28/2021
Modified by: Ramesh Karri
